json.text: Ok, here we go. This, quite a lot of people outside,
can I ask that you actually to come in, move closer to the
front because that gives more opportunity
for those in the back, to actually find
a nice place. There's lots of room
in the front and monks, we do have showers
so we dont smell, you can come much closer.
In fact the closer you get, the more
energy you can feel. I learnt from
our young President, that the people in the
front is called like the mosh pit
is that right? So these are the people in
the mosh pit, at the front,
moshies. Ok it's been a couple of weeks
since I've been giving a talk here. Cos' the last week I was just away,
there was no opportunity, the week before was
Ajahn Yanadhamma's but still always
get these requests over the fax machine
letters or emails to give talks
on certain subjects, and the request
which I got this evening, is to give
a talk on loneliness. And again, I love
being able to give talks on such subjects and
be able to weave the ideas of Buddhism and of
meditation around these themes, to really
allow people to understand not only
just what Buddhism is and what meditation
teaches and also how it applies to some
problems which we face from time to time
in the world, because loneliness is a problem
for many people. For some people it's a chronic
problem. The problem of loneliness which creates
an enormous amount of suffering and
even suicide in their lives. I think, for everybody,
there'll become a time when you are by
yourself and you may feel afraid to that sickness we
call loneliness. We'll talk about
loneness now, what it actually is, why is the
problem and obviously how we can actually
surmount that problem to transcend it.
And even be able to celebrate and enjoy
loneliness. I suppose that as a monk, I am
quite qualified to talk about loneliness
because being a monk you spend a lot of time
in solitude. Spending time in solitude, you are
alone. But it's very different than the
feelings of loneliness. Nevertheless I can
recall as a young monk, or even earlier as
a young person, and understanding actually
what loneliness was, understand why
there is such a loneness and actually how
overcome it. So to start off with,I always
like to start off with a story and I cant
help but telling a joke to begin with.
So this is this evening's joke about loneliness. I
was trying to find what is the appropriate
joke in my repertoire of used and well worn
jokes, some which is topical as well.
There's this three men who were victims
of the tsunami, they were washed away.
But fortunately they managed to survive
by being washed up on a desert island.
There was the American, the Englishman and
the Australian man. Now I know I was born
in England but I've been Australia for a long
time now. So, but anyway it was three or four
months people have stopped searching for
tsunami survivors so they were in big
trouble on this desert island. There was
plenty to eat and lots to drink but they
were getting terribly lonely. And one day
a bottle washed up on the beach. Then of course
if you are in such a situation and you've
read other people's jokes, you know you should
rub that bottle because there might be a genie in
it. There was a genie otherwise it would be
no joke. And the genie came out and
according to tradition which is well known
in all religions, the genie can only give
you 3 um 3 wishes. So the genie said it's
pretty obvious just one wish each. What could it
be? And of course the American said, "I wished
I was back in New York in a diner having a
proper meal for a change." Straightaway,
as soon as he made that wish, it was granted.
He disappeared from the island and he was
in a diner in New York having a nice
big hamburger. Oh, he was just so happy. And he
asked the Englishman, "Sir, what's your wish?"
"I wish I was in a pub, a nice English pub, in front of a pint of
beer." And as soon as he made that wish, it
was granted. There he was in a nice place
in an old country pub in England, in front of a nice
warm pint of beer , Oh, he was in heaven.
And he asked the Australian, "What do you want?"
And he said,
"Well, I dont know, maybe I should be at the
putty match, maybe I should be at the Buddhist
Society on a Friday night." He said, "I can't
make up my mind. I wish my two friends were
back here to help me decide." I'm surprised
you haven't heard that joke. Now we are getting serious
about loneliness. Because that happens to us
from time to time people are lonely, but
that sometimes as the first aspects of
loneliness, it is like sometimes, we, it is like all states of mind, all states of life
they always have the positive and negative
to it. Part of our problem when facing the
difficulties in life, is again, always looking at the negative
part of it and not actually seeing the
benefits of loneliness or like aloneness, rather.
It's wonderful being alone. You dont have
to sort of, decide what TV program you
want to watch without arguing with somebody else, you can
decide what you want to eat, you can decide
what you want to do, when you want to do it.
There's an incredible amount of freedom
being by yourself. There's also some dangers
or some non benefits, some, what you call, suffering
about being by yourself, not having someone
to talk to, share moments with. There's
also some bad side of being by oneself.
And this particular aspect of the good
side and bad side of all situations which
really brought to mind in one of the classic
stories which I bring up every now and again
I'm not sure when was the last time it was I brought this
up. It was a classic case when some years ago
two Thai ladies they came to see me and, they
were sisters. And they came after our meal
to actually ask their questions and they
had problems, they want to see a monk to try and
find some solutions for their problems. They were different
problems. The first one, the problem was her
husband. She was married, she's been married for
for a long time and had some marital problems.
In fact she couldnt stand her husband and
she wanted to know, "Should I get a divorce or should I
get some advice and try and work at these problems?"
But she was tended towards divorce and
I was telling her to see the nice
part of your husband. It's not all bad.
You know, when you get married, you see
the beautiful side of your husband, you
get into denial about his faults, when
you want to divorce, you get into denial
about his good parts, that's why you
married him. He's just a husband, that's all
So I talked to her about getting to see the
nice side of her husband. Actually there's
this story, I'm just going off onto a tangent
now. There's this wonderful story which
I told in Singapore some years ago about
a very, very skillful marriage counsellor.
Because he had a similar problem. A
client came to her and said have been married for
many, many years now, but my husband is
doesn't show interest in me anymore. In fact he
comes home late from the office. I dont know for sure
but I think he might be having an affair with
another woman. I want to get a divorce from
him." The marriage counsellor was very smart.
He said, "Look, he probably wants you to
get divorced from him. If you get
a divorce from him, you'd be
doing exactly what he wants. He'd be very
happy, said yeah. This is what you should
do when you want to get his
own back. Dont get divorced yet. What you
should do, is actually try and find a
nice, do a little bit of a face lift, get a nice hair
style, get some really nice clothes. Cos
after awhile, see if he can actually get into falling
in love with you again. It may take a while
but you know it can be done. Be really nice
to him, really tender, really kind, do
all the nice things which you think he
actually likes and the plan is that when
he starts to like you again, esp when
he starts to get in love with you again, then
divorce him." He said, "Yeah". So that
was the plan. If he can divorce you when he wants
you to get a divorce, so he gets to do
what he wants. So, she got a really nice
outfit, did herself up, was really kind to him,
was really, really pleasant, and every
week or two, the marriage counsellor would actually
have a visit. He said,"What was going on?
How's it going on?" She said, "Actually,
it's working because he's coming home earlier."
He said, "Great, keep it up." And every
2 weeks he started coming home earlier,
being more kind to her, a bit more tender
to her, a bit more loving, it's working.
Then, it came to a point when she didnt turn up
for her counselling sessions for about a
month, so the counsellor called her at
home. Said, "What's going on? You havent called.
Is he sort of becoming kinder to you?" She
said "Oh,yeah." "Is he being more sort of tender,
more loving?" She said, "Oh, yeah." "Is he
falling in love with you?" She said, "Yes
he has fallen in love with me." The
counsellor said, "Great,now's the time to
divorce him." "Oh,no, he's so nice." Now's
the big plan in the long run actually to get
that man, sort of back in line, by
being kind to them. But anyhow, if that
doesnt work for your marriage, this lady
had another solution for her marriage
because she was telling about the problems
with her husband. So when I figured sort
of, there was not, sort of solution there,
I started talking to her sister,
"So what's your problem?" Her problem
is, she was single. She couldnt find
a partner and when I suggested the obvious
solution, they werent interested.
It's obvious, you've got a husband
you dont want, she wants a husband, swap.
It's logical. But the deepest part of
that story was that, I told them afterwards,
talked to the wife, you've got what we call like wife suffering,
relationship suffering. And you think if
you can get rid of that husband, then
you would have no suffering anymore. But if
you get rid of your husband you will have
the suffering that your sister has, which
you call single person suffering.
It is a totally different type of suffering, but
you've got rid of those relationship suffering
now you've got single person suffering.
If you were single, if you can find a nice partner
you wont have single person suffering anymore, then
you will have married person suffering.
So what you are only doing, is just just changing
one type of suffering for another.
And this is actually with loneliness, so aloneness
Sometimes when we look at aloneness being by
ourself, sure there is a lot of suffering,
which we say being by alone, being by
yourself. But if you get another partner
or a friend or someone else to be with you,
it's not that the problem disappears,
it just changes its shape and changes its form,
instead of having lonely suffering, you have
being with others suffering instead.
So know that and know that with all situations
in our life, there's never any perfection there, in the
sense that it's always happiness, always
wonderful. You're just changing one
particular type of problem for another
problem. The problem of loneliness is
changed to being a problem being in society, being with
others, in socialising. I think we should
all remember that. Because then, instead of thinking this is a problem,
everything will be ok once I find a friend,
a partner, once I could join a club. That's
not true. Other problems come in their
stead. So because of that, the people say,
well what's the point. Ok, now I am by
myself, now with other people, now
I'm by myself again, is there some sort
of way out of all this? Of course there is a way out of this
We're always changing
our situation and think that, once I change
my situation, once I change my job, once I
change my partner, once I am by myself,
or once I am with others, once my kids grow
up, once I become a monk, once I stop being
a monk, once I do go here, once I stop doing
that, you think that is going to make us
happy? No. The point of life, the wisdom
which comes from us, is actually, if we are
by ourselves, instead of seeing the problem
with being by ourselves, see its beauty, see
its benefit, see in appreciation of being
by oneself, and if one is with others, stop looking at
the problems of being with others, to see its beauty, being
it's a wonder being able to share one's time with another person.
So it's changing from the negative attitude, thinking,
oh, this is terrible, this is wrong and change
it to a positive. It's what I call the
relationship we have with the moments of
our lives. It's not the moments themselves which
is the problems, it's not our situations,
our circumstances which is the problem.
It is how we relate to it. It's not just
being alone which is a problem. It's how
we relate to being alone, that is the problem.
It's not being married which is a problem.
It's how we relate to being married which is a problem.
It's not just sitting up here and talking to what,
300-400 people here,no, maybe over thousand on
the internet, that's not the problem. It's
how we relate to them, that's the problem
So it is a relationship problem. But the
relationship, in a deeper sense of the term,
is actually how we relate to what we are
experiencing. And in our practice of
Buddhism, in our practice of meditation,
in our practice of things, the thing in itself
is never the problem, it's how we look at it, that is the problem.
Someone was asking me to actually to also include
in this talk, the fact there is a new pope,
a Catholic pope now and talking about sin. What actually is it?
How do we relate to a new pope, how do
we relate to another religion. It's never
the religion which is the problem. It's the
relationship that is the problem. How we
relate to these things, how we relate to that
person, how we relate to the things of
our life. I mention that because we had a
wonderful afternoon yesterday, having the
9 of the monks from the Benedictine monastery
in New .... here, who came to our monastery down
in Serpentine, as they do once a year
for an afternoon of discussion about
spirituality. And this was a special occasion
because SBS were there as well. And they
were doing a documentary on this very wonderful
exchange which we had, and of course, just after
one or two minutes, we forgot the camera
was there. We were having this wonderful
exchange, from the Benedictine monastic perspective
and the Buddhist monastic perspective.
And we went on with that for 2 or 3 hours. We really
had some deep discussion about the nature
of God and the transcended and just how
we relate to those things. It was always,
yeah, I agree with that, yeah, but
yeah, I agree with you. And the people who
were actually doing the documentary, the reporter and also
the cameramen
were amazed, astounded. And afterwards they said
we were only supposed to get a few minutes, part of
a documentary but there's a whole documentary, what
they filmed yesterday. Just led you to see
just how two different religions can
relate together so well. And even though there are 2
different truths, how we can relate them
together and build up something which we have
in common. It's not the fact if you are
Christian or if you are a Buddhist or you are
girl or you are a boy or you are a Sri Lankan
or you are Australian or whatever
It's how you relate to that, that is where
we put sort of the effort in our life.
It's not that Christianity is the truth
and this is one of the problems with that
pope and this part that is going to create
a lot of problems. It's not that Buddhism is
the truth. The truth lies in the relationship
between the Buddhists and the Christians, that's
where the truth lies. And if that relationship
is anger, war, I dont want, controlling,
domination, or even just trying to destroy
when we know that relationship is not truth
But if it's one of listening, respecting,
discussing, love, peace and that relationship
that's what you know is truth, which is why I always
say when the Muslim Taliban destroyed those
big Buddhist statues in Bamiyan, they cant
destroy Buddhism that way. How they could have
destroyed Buddhism, is if the Buddhists got
angry and wanted revenge, you destroyed our
Buddhist, we're going to destroy your
mosques, then they would have
destroyed Buddhism which is the relationship
which we have with the events which happen
in our life. So someone hurts us, they
destroy our possessions, how do we relate to
that. Are we really creating this peace, this
understanding, this positive way of saying,
What can we do with this so we dont create
more destruction but we create more peace, more
harmony. We go forward rather than backwards
in life. So when it comes to something like
loneliness, there you are alone, that's not
going to destroy your happiness, it's the
relationship you have to being alone, that's
going to destroy your happiness if you
allow it. So we look at being alone,
why is it a problem? Cant we just enjoy
being by ourselves? I love being by myself.
but I also love being with you guys.
Sometimes, I live a very, very strange life.
I live a life of extremes. Cos many of you
know 2 or 3 years ago, I spent 6 months in absolute
solitude where I never even saw another
human being for 6 months, let alone talk
to them. I saw a few kangaroos and snakes
and all these other animals but not human beings.
That's for 6 months and, it was only a few
weeks ago when I was in Colombo, that's when
I was giving a talk in the middle of this
crowd of 10 thousand, now that's extremes.
One moment, 10 thousand people are looking at you,
and a few years before, no one even knew I was there,
completely disappeared. Now at these
both situations, it wasnt 6 months of
solitude which was a problem or difficulty
at all, it's how we are relating to that.
That which we relate is what's between
me and that experience. The same when you
are talking to ten thousand, it's what's
between you and those people, that's
what you focused on. We actually look what's
between us. Here we actually we let go of
the sense of self and them, me and you
or when you are by yourself, it's me and nobody.
This is that what's in between is where the
problems lie. So, it didnt really matter what
I was experiencing. It always became a
matter of how I am experiencing that, what am I
doing about it, how am I relating to this?
When you understand that's the reason,
why we can get into suffering or that's
the reason why can get free of suffering,
so many opportunities come into place
of how to deal with those many occasions
in your life when no one else is
going to be around. When I say what places
when no one else can be around, sometimes
you may be sitting here in this hall of
300, 400 people, and still feel very alone,
still be inside of yourself and relating
to this experience, is being alone.
Sometimes, as you know, loneliness is in the
whole crowd of people, sometimes you feel that.
Sometimes, aloneness, you can be sitting
in your own room or in your own home when no one
else is around, that can be there as well.
So sometimes you can't detect loneliness.
People can be with others but still
be very, very lonely. Which is why it does
happen , it's just a tragedy when
you do find people committing suicide and they are so lonely.
You wonder why, we got a family we talk
together, we meet together, we go out
together but they are lonely. It's how they are
relating to those times in their lives
when no on else is around.
And they are the majority of your time
in this world. This was one of the sayings,
I think of the Buddha but certainly I
remember my teacher Ajahn Chah, used to
say this a lot. He said, "You are born alone.
You die alone and much of the time you
spend in between is alone." I remember
that saying cos one of my friends,
who is the abbot of the monastery in
New Zealand. he told me when he went back to
his mother in Canada where he was talking
about Buddhism to her, he said "I was born alone,
I will die alone." She said "No, you werent, I was there."
Now that's the end of trying to convert his
mother to being a Buddhist. It's one thing
I found out through the other monks, "Monks
you cannot teach your mother anything. She's
taught you everything since you were small."
So I gave up on my mother a long time ago.
Other monks can teach my mother but I cant.
No way. Anyhow, back to being, like alone.
It's a lot of truth there, cos when you wake
up in the morning, you are alone. There you
are again, you have your thoughts filling
your body, even there maybe your wife, your husband
next to you, you still wake up alone.
This is where we can actually learn how we are
relating to that feeling there, that being
there, and being by oneself. I've been
training myself for many many years, and
I just do it automatically now. When I wake up
in the morning,you know my first thought
usually is, Good morning me, nice to see
you again. It's great to be able to have that
friendliness to this first moment, when you
wake up. What's the last thing I do
before I go to sleep at night, Good night,
Have a nice sleep, me. You may think that's
a joke but I do that and it makes a lot of
difference to your life. It's a simple thing.
Sometimes, the simple things, we think,
dont really count very much, they are not valuable.
We want some other sort of great technique to be able
to sort of get in the sense, in touch with ourselves,
and friendliness to ourselves, to overcome this
loneness but no, that really works. It starts the day off, with this beautiful feeling of
friendliness to yourself, you are relating
in a positive way, just by the feeling of good morning.
Sometimes I have great fun as a monk, esp
in the early years, especially whenever I go to places
where they dont really know monks very much
It's not so much fun now in Perth because people got to
know who you are and they recognise us
monks. When we first came here,
an example when I went to see my
mother in England for the first time.
We were walking down the streets of
London, you know what English people
are like, it's not just stiff upper lip,
the whole of them is stiff.
As I was going down these streets, every person
that I met, no matter who I was seeing, I said,
"Good morning" "good morning" and I know
English psychology, when someone says
good morning to you, you have to say
good morning back, even if you dont feel
like to doing it, even if it was from a weirdo
in a brown robe saying that to you. It was
psychological pressure and I put
all this psychological pressure to all
these people with a big smile, good morning
and they said, good morning, rrr.
It was great fun making people do this.
It's great fun being a monk.
As soon as they see someone weird, they want
to go on the other side of the road,
dont know whether you were going to convert
them or attack them or something.
One of the best times was when I was in
the midlands of England, my mother
used to come from Stoke-on-Trent, so
we had some relations in the midlands,
we went to go and see them.
Cos when you go and see this relation
and that relation, it takes a long time.
But anyway,in the morning, yeah, I wanted
to walk, have a bit of exercise. So I was
walking along the streets of Stoke-on-Trent
and all these people were pointing at me
and laughing. It's only afterwards
I found out there was a circus in town
and they thought I was one of the clowns.
I thought what a wonderful thing, I dont
mind that, great making people laugh.
So I never got upset. I thought, what a wonderful
opportunity, what a great privilege to
to create some laughter in Stoke-on-Trent
on a November, sort of, cold morning.
So when you dont worry about what people
think of you, you never get upset when
people laugh. Remember that one great
saying, which I said, which is actually in my book,
If anybody laughs because of your appearance
or what you said, always make sure you laugh
as well because then the world or any person
can never laugh at you, they can only
laugh with you. It's a beautiful saying.
So if you ever do something absolutely stupid and
ridiculous, make an idiot of yourself,
you laugh as well and the whole world
laughs with you, never laugh at you. So
this whole ego, this loneness, this self business
starts to disappear. So this is where I want
lead this talking to the, one of reasons
why people get afraid of loneliness it is
because of this self business which we have.
We have this thing called an identity.
Very often, loneliness is an identity crisis.
When we are by ourself we dont know who we
are, what we are supposed to do, how we
relate to life in itself. Too often
we have these sterotypes, that you are supposed to
have friends, that you are supposed to be
married, you are supposed to have kids,
you are supposed to have somebody there.
In being alone, you have the identity crisis,
not only feeling like a failure, we're no good,
we're hopeless,
we're useless but also we have the not
knowing how we fit into things in the world.
This, having an identity, fitting in, being
sort of someone who is somebody in this
world is such a strong demand of an ego,
of a self. There becomes always playing roles,
always trying to fit in, doing things.
I remember just sometimes, as a young man,
when I used to go and watch soccer
in London, just how you felt you were
somebody when you actually joined in that
crowd of maniacs shouting for a soccer team
or how the people if they go over to one
these Western darbies, Freemantle vs the Eagles,
why people enjoy that, because now they've
got an identity, they are an eagle supporter
they are ... supporter.
When we make these identities, these little
selves which we have, they are like
not just self but the take off the veil
it's like cells, we put ourselves in
this little prisons sometimes.
We feel good for a little while but
we dont really have any freedom.
Because eventually we have to stop that
being in the soccer crowd or being in the
footie crowd or being in a marriage or
being with other people, being in a crowd,
or being in a group. We cant
stay in that forever. When we are out of
that little, what is it called,
identification matrix, then we feel lost
we dont know who we are, what we mean.
It's an identity crisis. So often, when we actually think of actually who we
think we are, so often we define ourselves by our
family, by our marriage, by our job,
by our physical relationships in the world,
which I think is one of the reasons why when
people go through a divorce. It's not just
like losing a loved one, it's losing an identity
which causes a great deal of angst and suffering.
When you are by yourself,
It's not just not knowing what to do,
it's just not knowing who you are,
is one of the problems. This is actually
where Buddhism
probably all religions and paths
can really come to the rescue because
the rescue comes from this incredible path
and deep teaching of the Buddha called
'non-self'. In our world we're always
encouraged to make identities. I am the monk.
But when I was in Stoke-on-Trent, I wasnt a
monk, I was a clown. I just had an invitation
today from Singapore, just a few minutes ago,
they wanted to do a, apparently in Singapore,
there's a controversy, the government
of Singapore wants to open up a casino.
The different religions are actually, some are fighting it
some are questioning it, some are supporting it
I dont know what's happening over there.
They actually want me to go over there
during rains retreat, I had to refuse.
And they wanted actually to me, not to give a talk
but to take part in a play, in a skit, in a comedy routine
and that was actually quite attractive to me,
to decide. It wasnt generated to you,
then I would have said, yeah.
Cos that way I would not be a monk.
I would be like a comedian and the actor.
I dont know, as a monk these days,
sometimes you like changing your roles
to be doing something different.
It was at that time, it was a funny occasion,
many years ago, when I was not the abbot, not
so fat, I used to be like very active
on the building site of our monastery.
I was the main builder of my monastery
but now I have learnt how to delegate, now all the other
monks do it. They're really great
But I remember on this one occasion
I've been working. When you are actually working, you
wear your robes or your under robes,
and if you're actually building, you
get very dirty, you just can't help it
when you're mixing concrete or you're laying bricks or
you are shovelling dirt, you're going to get dirt
over you. So we've just finished the morning
work, we've been laying some concrete or making
some cement or something, we've been
covered in grey splodges of cement all over myself.
And I was actually walking back to the
dining hall for the luncheon,
there was this Sri Lankan lady who has come to visit.
Like many people who come to our monastery
they are very well dressed, it's a monastery,
actually a place of religion, not your
Sunday best but it was like your
Tuesday best, she was wearing.
So she came up to me and it was
first time, she said "I've come to bring
some food for the monks, where should we go?"
I said,"Well you could go up to that
dining room over there, you wait up
there, the abbot will be around in a
few minutes." I never told them
that I was the abbot. And I rushed to
my hut, had a very quick shower.
It's amazing how quick you can have a shower,
when you are mindful, 5 minutes got myself out,
put on some clean robes and go and see her.
Have a nice chat with her before she offered
food. Afterwards, she said, "It's really
inspiring, really good monastery here.
If you dont mind me saying something,
you should tell your monks to dress
properly, because I just came across that monk
before I came in here and he a mess
he was sloppy, and that's not right.
I'll tell him, I'll tell him
but it was me.
